docs.lead_paragraph: Lawson Software forecast third-quarter profit below analysts' estimates and said it would buy a health care software provider, Healthvision Solutions, in an all-cash deal valued at $160 million. Shares of Lawson, which makes software for businesses, fell as much as 8 percent in aftermarket trade. The purchase of Healthvision, which is privately held, will help Lawson Software expand its footprint in the health care software market, its chief executive, Harry Debes, said in a call with analysts. Lawson Software forecast third-quarter earnings of 7 cents to 9 cents a share, excluding special items, on revenue of $174 million to $178 million. Analysts had expected earnings of 10 cents a share, excluding one-time items, on revenue of $174.9 million.
docs.abstract: Lawson Software forecasts third-quarter profit below analysts estimates of 7 cents to 9 cents a share on revenue of $174 million to $178 million; says it has agreed to buy health care software provider Healthvision Solutions for $160 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a new analysis, the chief actuary of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services found that the Senate version of major health care legislation would increase total national health spending from 2010 to 2019 by $222.3 billion, or 0.6 percent, more than projected under current law.

headline.main: Actuary Still Sees Increase in Health Spending

docs.abstract: The chief actuary of the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services says that overall national health spending will increase as a result of the Senate version of major health care legislation, though some central provisions would help to lower costs over the long-term.

docs.lead_paragraph: Warren Buffett, the billionaire investor and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway, has spoken out in defense of Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, who has been under fire for supporting the Democrats' big health care legislation. Mr. Buffett said that he, too, would have voted for the bill, according to an article Friday in The Lincoln Journal Star.

headline.main: Buffett Says Nelson 'Did the Courageous Thing'

docs.abstract: The Oracle of Omaha comes out in defense of Nebraska Senator Ben Nelson.
docs.snippet: The Oracle of Omaha comes out in defense of Nebraska Senator Ben Nelson.

docs.lead_paragraph: Now that the House and Senate are trying to reconcile their separate health care bills, it seems worthwhile to compare the two bills on the elements most important to small businesses. There are crucial differences between the two. In general, small companies - or at least the most self-interested among them - are likely to prefer the Senate bill, which is more lenient on employers and insurers alike. Employees and those most concerned about the integrity of the reforms - whether they'll actually do what they're supposed to do - are likely to gravitate toward the House version.

headline.main: Comparing the House and Senate Health Care Bills

docs.abstract: In general, small companies are likely to prefer the Senate version, which is more lenient on employers and insurers alike.
docs.snippet: In general, small companies are likely to prefer the Senate version, which is more lenient on employers and insurers alike.
